Liber Libræ.author: Aleister Crowley
Liber Libræ.description: Karma Yoga. Um curso básico de moralidade ao homem comum.

I.0: 0. Learn first — Oh thou who aspirest unto our ancient Order! — that Equilibrium is the basis of the Work. If thou thyself hast not a sure foundation, whereon wilt thou stand to direct the forces of Nature?
I.1: 1. Know then, that as man is born into this world amidst the Darkness of Matter, and the strife of contending forces; so must his first endeavour be to seek the Light through their reconciliation.
I.2: 2. Thou then, who hast trials and troubles, rejoice because of them, for in them is Strength, and by their means is a pathway opened unto that Light.
I.3:
3. How should it be otherwise, O man, whose life is but a day in Eternity, a drop in the Ocean of time; how, were thy trials not many, couldst thou purge thy soul from the dross of earth?

Is it but now that the Higher Life is beset with dangers and difficulties; hath it not ever been so with the Sages and Hierophants of the past? They have been persecuted and reviled, they have been tormented of men; yet through this also has their Glory increased.
I.4: 4. Rejoice therefore, O Initiate, for the greater thy trial the greater thy Triumph. When men shall revile thee, and speak against thee falsely, hath not the Master said, “Blessed art thou!”?
I.5: 5. Yet, oh aspirant, let thy victories bring thee not Vanity, for with increase of Knowledge should come increase of Wisdom. He who knoweth little, thinketh he knoweth much; but he who knoweth much hath learned his own ignorance. Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? There is more hope of a fool, than of him.
I.6: 6. Be not hasty to condemn others; how knowest thou that in their place, thou couldest have resisted the temptation? And even were it so, why shouldst thou despise one who is weaker than thyself?
I.7: 7. Thou therefore who desirest Magical Gifts, be sure that thy soul is firm and steadfast; for it is by flattering thy weaknesses that the Weak Ones will gain power over thee. Humble thyself before thy Self, yet fear neither man nor spirit. Fear is failure, and the forerunner of failure: and courage is the beginning of virtue.
I.8: 8. Therefore fear not the Spirits, but be firm and courteous with them; for thou hast no right to despise or revile them; and this too may lead thee astray. Command and banish them, curse them by the Great Names if need be; but neither mock nor revile them, for so assuredly wilt thou be lead into error.
I.9: 9. A man is what he maketh himself within the limits fixed by his inherited destiny; he is a part of mankind; his actions affect not only what he calleth himself, but also the whole universe.
I.10: 10. Worship and neglect not, the physical body which is thy temporary connection with the outer and material world. Therefore let thy mental Equilibrium be above disturbance by material events; strengthen and control the animal passions, discipline the emotions and the reason, nourish the Higher Aspirations.
I.11: 11. Do good unto others for its own sake, not for reward, not for gratitude from them, not for sympathy. If thou art generous, thou wilt not long for thine ears to be tickled by expressions of gratitude.
I.12: 12. Remember that unbalanced force is evil; that unbalanced severity is but cruelty and oppression; but that also unbalanced mercy is but weakness which would allow and abet Evil. Act passionately; think rationally; be Thyself.
I.13: 13. True ritual is as much action as word; it is Will.
I.14: 14. Remember that this earth is but an atom in the universe, and that thou thyself art but an atom thereon, and that even couldst thou become the God of this earth whereon thou crawlest and grovellest, that thou wouldest, even then, be but an atom, and one amongst many.
I.15: 15. Nevertheless have the greatest self-respect, and to that end sin not against thyself. The sin which is unpardonable is knowingly and wilfully to reject truth, to fear knowledge lest that knowledge pander not to thy prejudices.
I.16: 16. To obtain Magical Power, learn to control thought; admit only those ideas that are in harmony with the end desired, and not every stray and contradictory Idea that presents itself.
I.17: 17. Fixed thought is a means to an end. Therefore pay attention to the power of silent thought and meditation. The material act is but the outward expression of thy thought, and therefore hath it been said that “the thought of foolishness is sin.” Thought is the commencement of action, and if a chance thought can produce much effect, what cannot fixed thought do?
I.18: 18. Therefore, as hath already been said, Establish thyself firmly in the equilibrium of forces, in the centre of the Cross of the Elements, that Cross from whose centre the Creative Word issued in the birth of the Dawning Universe.
I.19: 19. Be thou therefore prompt and active as the Sylphs, but avoid frivolity and caprice; be energetic and strong like the Salamanders, but avoid irritability and ferocity; be flexible and attentive to images like the Undines, but avoid idleness and changeability; be laborious and patient like the Gnomes, but avoid grossness and avarice.
I.20: 20. So shalt thou gradually develop the powers of thy soul, and fit thyself to command the Spirits of the elements. For wert thou to summon the Gnomes to pander to thine avarice, thou wouldst no longer command them, but they would command thee. Wouldst thou abuse the pure beings of the woods and mountains to fill thy coffers and satisfy thy hunger of Gold? Wouldst thou debase the Spirits of Living Fire to serve thy wrath and hatred? Wouldst thou violate the purity of the Souls of the Waters to pander to thy lust of debauchery? Wouldst thou force the Spirits of the Evening Breeze to minister to thy folly and caprice? Know that with such desires thou canst but attract the Weak, not the Strong, and in that case the Weak will have power over thee.
I.21: 21. In the true religion there is no sect, therefore take heed that thou blaspheme not the name by which another knoweth his God; for if thou do this thing in Jupiter thou wilt blaspheme יהוה and in Osiris יהשוה. Ask and ye shall have! Seek, and ye shall find! Knock, and it shall be opened unto you!

I.0: 0. Aprende primeiro — Ó tu que aspiras à nossa antiga Ordem! — que Equilíbrio é a base do Trabalho. Se tu mesmo não tens um alicerce firme, sobre o que tu ficarás para dirigir as forças da Natureza?
I.1: 1. Então saiba que já que o homem nasce neste mundo em meio à Escuridão da Matéria e à disputa de forças conflitantes; portanto, seu primeiro esforço deve ser o de buscar a Luz através de sua reconciliação.
I.2: 2. Então, tu que tens provações e problemas, regozija-te por causa deles, pois neles há Força, e por sua via se abre um caminho para a Luz.
I.3:
3. Como de outra forma, ó homem, cuja vida é apenas um dia na Eternidade, uma gota no Oceano do tempo; como, se tuas provações não fossem muitas, tu poderias purificar tua alma da impureza da terra?

É só agora que a Vida Superior é ameaçada por perigos e dificuldades; não tem sido sempre assim com os Sábios e Hierofantes do passado? Eles foram perseguidos e injuriados, eles foram atormentados pelos homens; no entanto através disso também aumentou sua Glória.
I.4: 4. Portanto alegra-te, Ó Iniciado, pois quanto maior a tua prova, maior o teu Triunfo. Quando os homens te injuriarem, e falarem falsamente contra ti, não disse o Mestre: “Abençoado és tu!”?
I.5: 5. No entanto, ó aspirante, que as tuas vitórias não te tragam Vaidade, pois com o aumento do Conhecimento virá o aumento da Sabedoria. Aquele que conhece pouco, pensa que conhece muito; mas aquele que conhece muito aprendeu sobre sua própria ignorância. Vês um homem sábio em sua própria presunção? Há mais esperança em um tolo do que nele.
I.6: 6. Não sejas precipitado em condenar os outros; como tu sabes que em seu lugar tu poderias ter resistido à tentação? E mesmo assim, por que tu deverias desprezar alguém que é mais fraco do que ti?
I.7: 7. Portanto, tu que desejas Dons Mágicos, tenha certeza de que tua alma é firme e inabalável; pois é lisonjeando as tuas fraquezas que os Fracos ganharão poder sobre ti. Humilha-te diante do teu Self, mas não tema nem homem e nem espírito. Medo é o fracasso, e o precursor do fracasso: e coragem é o princípio da virtude.
I.8: 8. Portanto, não temas os Espíritos, mas seja firme e cortês com eles; pois tu não tens direito de desprezá-los ou ofendê-los; e isso também pode te desviar. Comanda-os e bana-os, amaldiçoa-os pelos Grandes Nomes se necessário for; mas não os zombes ou injuries, pois desta forma tu seguramente serás levado ao erro.
I.9: 9. Um homem é o que ele faz de si mesmo dentro dos limites fixados pelo seu destino herdado; ele é uma parte da humanidade; suas ações afetam não só o que ele mesmo chama, mas também todo o universo.
I.10: 10. Venere, e não negligencie, o corpo físico, que é a tua conexão temporária com o mundo externo e material. Portanto, que o teu Equilíbrio mental esteja acima da perturbação por eventos materiais; fortalece e controle as paixões animais, discipline as emoções e a razão, nutre as Aspirações Superiores.
I.11: 11. Faze o bem aos outros apenas por fazer, não por recompensa, não pela gratidão deles, não por simpatia. Se tu és generoso, não desejarás que teus ouvidos sejam agraciados por expressões de gratidão.
I.12: 12. Lembre-te de que a força desequilibrada é maligna; que a severidade desequilibrada é apenas crueldade e opressão; mas também que a misericórdia desequilibrada é apenas fraqueza que permitiria e instigaria o Mal. Age apaixonadamente; pense racionalmente; sê Tu mesmo.
I.13: 13. Verdadeiro ritual é tanto ação quanto palavra; é Vontade.
I.14: 14. Lembre-te de que esta terra é apenas um átomo no universo, e que tu mesmo és apenas um átomo sobre a mesma, e que, mesmo que tu te tornastes o Deus desta terra sobre a qual tu te arrastas e rastejas, que tu serias, mesmo assim, apenas um átomo, e um dentre muitos.
I.15: 15. No entanto, tenha o maior auto respeito e, para esse fim, não peque contra ti mesmo. O pecado que é imperdoável é conscientemente e deliberadamente rejeitar a verdade, temer o conhecimento porque ele não gratifica os teus preconceitos.
I.16: 16. Para obter Poder Mágico, aprende a controlar o pensamento; admite apenas as ideias que estão em harmonia com o fim desejado, e não toda Ideia dispersa e contraditória que se apresenta.
I.17: 17. Pensamento fixo é um meio para um fim. Portanto, preste atenção ao poder do pensamento silencioso e da meditação. O ato material é apenas a expressão externa do teu pensamento, e por isso foi dito que “pensar tolice é pecado”. Pensamento é o início da ação, e se um pensamento casual pode produzir muito efeito, o que o pensamento fixo não pode fazer?
I.18: 18. Portanto, como já foi dito: Estabelece-te firmemente no equilíbrio das forças, no centro da Cruz dos Elementos, aquela Cruz de cujo centro a Palavra Criativa proferiu no nascimento do Universo alvorecendo.
I.19: 19. Portanto, sê rápido e ativo como os Silfos, mas evite frivolidades e caprichos; sê energético e forte como as Salamandras, mas evite irritabilidade e ferocidade; sê flexível e atento a imagens como as Ondinas, mas evite ociosidade e inconstância; sê laborioso e paciente como os Gnomos, mas evite a grosseria e a avareza.
I.20: 20. Assim gradualmente desenvolverás os poderes da tua alma e te tornarás apto a comandar os Espíritos dos elementos. Pois se convocasses os Gnomos para gratificar tua avareza, tu não mais os comandaria, mas eles te comandariam. Tu abusarias dos seres puros dos bosques e das montanhas para encher teus cofres e satisfazer tua fome de Ouro? Tu rebaixarias os Espíritos do Fogo Vivo para servir tua ira e ódio? Tu violarias a pureza das Almas das Águas para gratificar a tua luxúria de devassidão? Tu forçarias os Espíritos da Brisa da Noite a ministrar tua loucura e capricho? Saiba que com tais desejos tu só podes atrair o Fraco, não o Forte, e neste caso o Fraco terá poder sobre ti.
I.21: 21. Não há seita na verdadeira religião, portanto, tome cuidado para que não blasfemes o nome pelo qual outro conhece seu Deus; pois se tu fazes isso em Júpiter, tu blasfemarás יהוה e em Osíris יהשוה . Pedi e vós tereis! Procurai e vós encontrareis! Batei e será aberto para vós!

∅.15: 15. An end to loneliness, as to all.

I.1: 1. My God, how I love Thee!
I.2: 2. With the vehement appetite of a beast I hunt Thee through the Universe.
I.3: 3. Thou art standing as it were upon a pinnacle at the edge of some fortified city. I am a white bird, and perch upon Thee.
I.4: 4. Thou art My Lover: I see Thee as a nymph with her white limbs stretched by the spring.
I.5: 5. She lies upon the moss; there is none other but she:
I.7: 7. I am He. Speak not, O my God! Let the work be accomplished in silence.
I.8: 8. Let my cry of pain be crystallized into a little white fawn to run away into the forest!
I.9: 9. Thou art a centaur, O my God, from the violet-blossoms that crown Thee to the hoofs of the horse.
I.10: 10. Thou art harder than tempered steel; there is no diamond beside Thee.
I.11: 11. Did I not yield this body and soul?
I.12: 12. I woo thee with a dagger drawn across my throat.
I.13: 13. Let the spout of blood quench Thy blood-thirst, O my God!
I.14: 14. Thou art a little white rabbit in the burrow Night.
I.15: 15. I am greater than the fox and the hole.
I.16: 16. Give me Thy kisses, O Lord God!
I.17: 17. The lightning came and licked up the little flock of sheep.
I.18: 18. There is a tongue and a flame; I see that trident walking over the sea.
I.19: 19. A phœnix hath it for its head; below are two prongs. They spear the wicked.
I.20: 20. I will spear Thee, O Thou little grey god, unless Thou beware!
I.21: 21. From the grey to the gold; from the gold to that which is beyond the gold of Ophir.
I.22: 22. My God! but I love Thee!
I.23: 23. Why hast Thou whispered so ambiguous things? Wast Thou afraid, O goat-hoofed One, O horned One, O pillar of lightning?
I.24: 24. From the lightning fall pearls; from the pearls black specks of nothing.
I.25: 25. I based all on one, one on naught.
I.26: 26. Afloat in the æther, O my God, my God!
I.27: 27. O Thou great hooded sun of glory, cut off these eyelids!
I.28: 28. Nature shall die out; she hideth me, closing mine eyelids with fear, she hideth me from My destruction, O Thou open eye.
I.30: 30. Not Isis my mother, nor Osiris my self; but the incestuous Horus given over to Typhon, so may I be!
I.31: 31. There thought; and thought is evil.
I.32: 32. Pan! Pan! Io Pan! it is enough.
I.33: 33. Fall not into death, O my soul! Think that death is the bed into which you are falling!
I.34: 34. O how I love Thee, O my God! Especially is there a vehement parallel light from infinity, vilely diffracted in the haze of this mind.
I.35:
35. I love Thee.
I love Thee.
I love Thee.
I.36: 36. Thou art a beautiful thing whiter than a woman in the column of this vibration.
I.37: 37. I shoot up vertically like an arrow, and become that Above.
I.38: 38. But it is death, and the flame of the pyre.
I.39: 39. Ascend in the flame of the pyre, O my soul! Thy God is like the cold emptiness of the utmost heaven, into which thou radiatest thy little light.
I.40: 40. When Thou shall know me, O empty God, my flame shall utterly expire in Thy great N. O. X.
I.41: 41. What shalt Thou be, my God, when I have ceased to love Thee?
I.42: 42. A worm, a nothing, a niddering knave!
I.44: 44. I have thrown a million flowers from the basket of the Beyond at Thy feet, I have anointed Thee and Thy Staff with oil and blood and kisses.
I.45: 45. I have kindled Thy marble into life — ay! into death.
I.46: 46. I have been smitten with the reek of Thy mouth, that drinketh never wine but life.
I.47: 47. How the dew of the Universe whitens the lips!
I.48: 48. Ah! trickling flow of the stars of the mother Supernal, begone!
I.49: 49. I Am She that should come, the Virgin of all men.
I.50: 50. I am a boy before Thee, O Thou satyr God.
I.51: 51. Thou wilt inflict the punishment of pleasure — Now! Now! Now!
I.52: 52. Io Pan! Io Pan! I love Thee. I love Thee.
I.55: 55. I cried aloud the word — and it was a mighty spell to bind the Invisible, an enchantment to unbind the bound; yea, to unbind the bound.

II.1: 1. O my God! use Thou me again, alway. For ever! For ever!
II.2: 2. That which came fire from Thee cometh water from me; let therefore Thy Spirit lay hold on me, so that my right hand loose the lightning.
II.3: 3. Travelling through space, I saw the onrush of two galaxies, butting each other and goring like bulls upon earth. I was afraid.
II.4: 4. Thus they ceased fight, and turned upon me, and I was sorely crushed and torn.
II.5: 5. I had rather have been trampled by the World-Elephant.
II.6: 6. O my God! Thou art my little pet tortoise!
II.8: 8. I creep under Thy carapace, like a lover into the bed of his beautiful; I creep in, and sit in Thine heart, as cubby and cosy as may be.
II.9: 9. Thou shelterest me, that I hear not the trumpeting of that World-Elephant.
II.10: 10. Thou art not worth an obol in the agora; yet Thou art not to be bought at the ransom of the whole Universe.
II.11: 11. Thou art like a beautiful Nubian slave leaning her naked purple against the green pillars of marble that are above the bath.
II.12: 12. Wine jets from her black nipples.
II.13: 13. I drank wine awhile agone in the house of Pertinax. The cup-boy favoured me, and gave me of the right sweet Chian.
II.14:
14. There was a Doric boy, skilled in feats of strength, an athlete. The full moon fled away angrily down the wrack.
Ah! but we laughed.
II.15: 15. I was pernicious drunk, O my God! Yet Pertinax brought me to the bridal.
II.16: 16. I had a crown of thorns for all my dower.
II.17: 17. Thou art like a goat’s horn from Astor, O Thou God of mine, gnarl’d and crook’d and devilish strong.
II.18: 18. Colder than all the ice of all the glaciers of the Naked Mountain was the wine it poured for me.
II.19:
19. A wild country and a waning moon.
Clouds scudding over the sky.
A circuit of pines, and of tall yews beyond. Thou in the midst!
II.20: 20. O all ye toads and cats, rejoice! Ye slimy things, come hither!
II.21: 21. Dance, dance to the Lord our God!
II.22: 22. He is he! He is he! He is he!
II.24: 24. Why? Why? comes the sudden cackle of a million imps of hell.
II.26: 26. But sickens not the Universe; but shakes not the stars.
II.28: 28. I am walking in an asylum; all the men and women about me are insane.
II.29: 29. Oh madness! madness! madness! desirable art thou!
II.30: 30. But I love Thee, O God!
II.31: 31. These men and women rave and howl; they froth out folly.
II.32: 32. I begin to be afraid. I have no check; I am alone. Alone. Alone.
II.33: 33. Think, O God, how I am happy in Thy love.
II.34: 34. O marble Pan! O false leering face! I love Thy dark kisses, bloody and stinking! O marble Pan! Thy kisses are like sunlight on the blue Ægean; their blood is the blood of the sunset over Athens; their stink is like a garden of Roses of Macedonia.
II.35: 35. I dreamt of sunset and roses and vines; Thou wast there, O my God, Thou didst habit Thyself as an Athenian courtesan, and I loved Thee.
II.36: 36. Thou art no dream, O Thou too beautiful alike for sleep and waking!
II.37: 37. I disperse the insane folk of the earth; I walk alone with my little puppets in the garden.
II.38: 38. I am Gargantuan great; yon galaxy is but the smoke-ring of mine incense.
II.39: 39. Burn Thou strange herbs, O God!
II.40: 40. Brew me a magic liquor, boys, with your glances!
II.42: 42. Thou art drunken, O my God, upon my kisses.
II.43: 43. The Universe reels; Thou hast looked upon it.
II.45: 45. Come, O my God, and let us embrace!
II.46: 46. Lazily, hungrily, ardently, patiently; so will I work.
II.49: 49. I am a fool to love Thee; Thou art cruel, Thou withholdest Thyself.
II.50: 50. Come to me now! I love Thee! I love Thee!
II.51: 51. O my darling, my darling — Kiss me! Kiss me! Ah! but again.
II.52: 52. Sleep, take me! Death, take me! This life is too full; it pains, it slays, it suffices.
II.53: 53. Let me go back into the world; yea, back into the world.

III.1: 1. I was the priest of Ammon-Ra in the temple of Ammon-Ra at Thebai.
III.2: 2. But Bacchus came singing with his troops of vine-clad girls, of girls in dark mantles; and Bacchus in the midst like a fawn!
III.3: 3. God! how I ran out in my rage and scattered the chorus!
III.4: 4. But in my temple stood Bacchus as the priest of Ammon-Ra.
III.5: 5. Therefore I went wildly with the girls into Abyssinia; and there we abode and rejoiced.
III.7: 7. I will eat the ripe and the unripe fruit for the glory of Bacchus.
III.8: 8. Terraces of ilex, and tiers of onyx and opal and sardonyx leading up to the cool green porch of malachite.
III.9: 9. Within is a crystal shell, shaped like an oyster — O glory of Priapus! O beatitude of the Great Goddess!
III.11: 11. O Pearl! thou hast come from the majesty of dread Ammon-Ra.
III.12: 12. Then I the priest beheld a steady glitter in the heart of the pearl.
III.13: 13. So bright we could not look! But behold! a blood-red rose upon a rood of glowing gold!
III.14: 14. So I adored the God. Bacchus! thou art the lover of my God!
III.15: 15. I who was priest of Ammon-Ra, who saw the Nile flow by for many moons, for many, many moons, am the young fawn of the grey land.
III.16: 16. I will set up my dance in your conventicles, and my secret loves shall be sweet among you.
III.17: 17. Thou shalt have a lover among the lords of the grey land.
III.18: 18. This shall he bring unto thee, without which all is in vain; a man’s life spilt for thy love upon My Altars.
III.20: 20. Let it be soon, O God, my God! I ache for Thee, I wander very lonely among the mad folk, in the grey land of desolation.
III.21: 21. Thou shalt set up the abominable lonely Thing of wickedness. Oh joy! to lay that corner-stone!
III.22: 22. It shall stand erect upon the high mountain; only my God shall commune with it.
III.23: 23. I will build it of a single ruby; it shall be seen from afar off.
III.24: 24. Come! let us irritate the vessels of the earth: they shall distil strange wine.
III.25: 25. It grows under my hand: it shall cover the whole heaven.
III.26: 26. Thou art behind me: I scream with a mad joy.
III.27: 27. Then said Ithuriel the strong; let Us also worship this invisible marvel!
III.28: 28. So did they, and the archangels swept over the heaven.
III.29: 29. Strange and mystic, like a yellow priest invoking mighty flights of great grey birds from the North, so do I stand and invoke Thee!
III.30: 30. Let them obscure not the sun with their wings and their clamour!
III.31: 31. Take away form and its following!
III.33: 33. Thou art like an osprey among the rice, I am the great red pelican in the sunset waters.
III.34: 34. I am like a black eunuch; and Thou art the scimitar. I smite off the head of the light one, the breaker of bread and salt.
III.35: 35. Yea! I smite — and the blood makes as it were a sunset on the lapis lazuli of the King’s Bedchamber.
III.36: 36. I smite! The whole world is broken up into a mighty wind, and a voice cries aloud in a tongue that men cannot speak.
III.37: 37. I know that awful sound of primal joy; let us follow on the wings of the gale even unto the holy house of Hathor; let us offer the five jewels of the cow upon her altar!
III.39: 39. I rear my Titan bulk into the teeth of the gale, and I smite and prevail, and swing me out over the sea.
III.40: 40. There is a strange pale God, a god of pain and deadly wickedness.
III.41: 41. My own soul bites into itself, like a scorpion ringed with fire.
III.42: 42. That pallid God with face averted, that God of subtlety and laughter, that young Doric God, him will I serve.
III.43: 43. For the end thereof is torment unspeakable.
III.44: 44. Better the loneliness of the great grey sea!
III.45: 45. But ill befall the folk of the grey land, my God!
III.46: 46. Let me smother them with my roses!
III.47: 47. Oh Thou delicious God, smile sinister!
III.48: 48. I pluck Thee, O my God, like a purple plum upon a sunny tree. How Thou dost melt in my mouth, Thou consecrated sugar of the Stars!
III.49: 49. The world is all grey before mine eyes; it is like an old worn wine-skin.
III.50: 50. All the wine of it is on these lips.
III.51: 51. Thou hast begotten me upon a marble Statue, O my God!
III.52: 52. The body is icy cold with the coldness of a million moons; it is harder than the adamant of eternity. How shall I come forth into the light?
III.53: 53. Thou art He, O God! O my darling! my child! my plaything! Thou art like a cluster of maidens, like a multitude of swans upon the lake.
III.54: 54. I feel the essence of softness.
III.55: 55. I am hard and strong and male; but come Thou! I shall be soft and weak and feminine.
III.56: 56. Thou shalt crush me in the wine-press of Thy love. My blood shall stain Thy fiery feet with litanies of Love in Anguish.
III.57: 57. There shall be a new flower in the fields, a new vintage in the vineyards.
III.58: 58. The bees shall gather a new honey; the poets shall sing a new song.
III.59: 59. I shall gain the Pain of the Goat for my prize; and the God that sitteth upon the shoulders of Time shall drowse.
III.60: 60. Then shall all this which is written be accomplished: yea, it shall be accomplished.

IV.1: 1. I am like a maiden bathing in a clear pool of fresh water.
IV.2: 2. O my God! I see Thee dark and desirable, rising through the water as a golden smoke.
IV.3: 3. Thou art altogether golden, the hair and the eyebrows and the brilliant face; even into the finger-tips and toe-tips Thou art one rosy dream of gold.
IV.4: 4. Deep into Thine eyes that are golden my soul leaps, like an archangel menacing the sun.
IV.5: 5. My sword passes through and through Thee; crystalline moons ooze out of Thy beautiful body that is hidden behind the ovals of Thine eyes.
IV.6: 6. Deeper, ever deeper. I fall, even as the whole Universe falls down the abyss of Years.
IV.7: 7. For Eternity calls; the Overworld calls; the world of the Word is awaiting us.
IV.8: 8. Be done with speech, O God! Fasten the fangs of the hound Eternity in this my throat!
IV.9: 9. I am like a wounded bird flapping in circles.
IV.10: 10. Who knows where I shall fall?
IV.11: 11. O blesséd One! O God! O my devourer!
IV.12: 12. Let me fall, fall down, fall away, afar, alone!
IV.14: 14. Nor is there any rest, Sweet Heart, save in the cradle of royal Bacchus, the thigh of the most Holy One.
IV.15: 15. There rest, under the canopy of night.
IV.16: 16. Uranus chid Eros; Marsyas chid Olympas; I chid my beautiful lover with his sunray mane; shall I not sing?
IV.17: 17. Shall not mine incantations bring around me the wonderful company of the wood-gods, their bodies glistening with the ointment of moonlight and honey and myrrh?
IV.18: 18. Worshipful are ye, O my lovers; let us forward to the dimmest hollow!
IV.19: 19. There we will feast upon mandrake and upon moly!
IV.20: 20. There the lovely One shall spread us His holy banquet. In the brown cakes of corn we shall taste the food of the world, and be strong.
IV.21: 21. In the ruddy and awful cup of death we shall drink the blood of the world, and be drunken!
IV.22: 22. Ohe! the song to Iao, the song to Iao!
IV.23: 23. Come, let us sing to thee, Iacchus invisible, Iacchus triumphant, Iacchus indicible!
IV.24: 24. Iacchus, O Iacchus, O Iacchus, be near us!
IV.25: 25. Then was the countenance of all time darkened, and the true light shone forth.
IV.26: 26. There was also a certain cry in an unknown tongue, whose stridency troubled the still waters of my soul, so that my mind and my body were healed of their disease, self-knowledge.
IV.27: 27. Yea, an angel troubled the waters.
IV.28: 28. This was the cry of Him: IIIOOShBTh-IO-IIIIAMAMThIBI-II.
IV.29: 29. Nor did I sing this for a thousand times a night for a thousand nights before Thou camest, O my flaming God, and pierced me with Thy spear. Thy scarlet robe unfolded the whole heavens, so that the Gods said: All is burning: it is the end.
IV.30: 30. Also Thou didst set Thy lips to the wound and suck out a million eggs. And Thy mother sat upon them, and lo! stars and stars and ultimate Things whereof stars are the atoms.
IV.31: 31. Then I perceived Thee, O my God, sitting like a white cat upon the trellis-work of the arbour; and the hum of the spinning worlds was but Thy pleasure.
IV.32: 32. O white cat, the sparks fly from Thy fur! Thou dost crackle with splitting the worlds.
IV.33: 33. I have seen more of Thee in the white cat than I saw in the Vision of Æons.
IV.34: 34. In the boat of Ra did I travel, but I never found upon the visible Universe any being like unto Thee!
IV.35: 35. Thou wast like a winged white horse, and I raced Thee through eternity against the Lord of the Gods.
IV.37: 37. Thou wast like a flake of snow falling in the pine-clad woods.
IV.38: 38. In a moment Thou wast lost in a wilderness of the like and the unlike.
IV.39: 39. But I beheld the beautiful God at the back of the blizzard — and Thou wast He!
IV.40: 40. Also I read in a great Book.
IV.41: 41. On ancient skin was written in letters of gold: Verbum fit Verbum.
IV.42:
42. Also Vitriol and the hierophant’s name
V.V.V.V.V.
IV.43: 43. All this wheeled in fire, in star-fire, rare and far and utterly lonely — even as Thou and I, O desolate soul my God!
IV.44:
44. Yea, and the writing
is well.
This is the voice which shook the earth.
IV.45: 45. Eight times he cried aloud, and by eight and by eight shall I count Thy favours, Oh Thou Elevenfold God 418!
IV.46: 46. Yea, and by many more; by the ten in the twenty-two directions; even as the perpendicular of the Pyramid — so shall Thy favours be.
IV.47: 47. If I number them, they are One.
IV.48: 48. Excellent is Thy love, Oh Lord! Thou art revealed by the darkness, and he who gropeth in the horror of the groves shall haply catch Thee, even as a snake that seizeth on a little singing-bird.
IV.49: 49. I have caught Thee, O my soft thrush; I am like a hawk of mother-of-emerald; I catch Thee by instinct, though my eyes fail from Thy glory.
IV.50: 50. Yet they are but foolish folk yonder. I see them on the yellow sand, all clad in Tyrian purple.
IV.51: 51. They draw their shining God unto the land in nets; they build a fire to the Lord of Fire, and cry unhallowed words, even the dreadful curse Amri maratza, maratza, atman deona lastadza maratza maritza — marán!
IV.52: 52. Then do they cook the shining god, and gulp him whole.
IV.53: 53. These are evil folk, O beautiful boy! let us pass on to the Otherworld.
IV.54: 54. Let us make ourselves into a pleasant bait, into a seductive shape!
IV.55: 55. I will be like a splendid naked woman with ivory breasts and golden nipples; my whole body shall be like the milk of the stars. I will be lustrous and Greek, a courtesan of Delos, of the unstable Isle.
IV.56: 56. Thou shalt be like a little red worm on a hook.
IV.57: 57. But thou and I will catch our fish alike.
IV.58: 58. Then wilt thou be a shining fish with golden back and silver belly: I will be like a violent beautiful man, stronger than two score bulls, a man of the West bearing a great sack of precious jewels upon a staff that is greater than the axis of the all.
IV.59: 59. And the fish shall be sacrificed to Thee and the strong man crucified for Me, and Thou and I will kiss, and atone for the wrong of the Beginning; yea, for the wrong of the beginning.

V.1: 1. O my beautiful God! I swim in Thy heart like a trout in the mountain torrent.
V.2: 2. I leap from pool to pool in my joy; I am goodly with brown and gold and silver.
V.3: 3. Why, I am lovelier than the russet autumn woods at the first snowfall.
V.4: 4. And the crystal cave of my thought is lovelier than I.
V.5: 5. Only one fish-hook can draw me out; it is a woman kneeling by the bank of the stream. It is she that pours the bright dew over herself, and into the sand so that the river gushes forth.
V.6: 6. There is a bird on yonder myrtle; only the song of that bird can draw me out of the pool of Thy heart, O my God!
V.7: 7. Who is this Neapolitan boy that laughs in his happiness? His lover is the mighty crater of the Mountain of Fire. I saw his charred limbs borne down the slopes in a stealthy tongue of liquid stone.
V.8: 8. And Oh! the chirp of the cicada!
V.9: 9. I remember the days when I was cacique in Mexico.
V.10: 10. O my God, wast Thou then as now my beautiful lover?
V.11: 11. Was my boyhood then as now Thy toy, Thy joy?
V.12: 12. Verily, I remember those iron days.
V.13: 13. I remember how we drenched the bitter lakes with our torrent of gold; how we sank the treasurable image in the crater of Citlaltepetl.
V.14: 14. How the good flame lifted us even unto the lowlands, setting us down in the impenetrable forest.
V.15: 15. Yea, Thou wast a strange scarlet bird with a bill of gold. I was Thy mate in the forests of the lowland; and ever we heard from afar the shrill chant of mutilated priests and the insane clamour of the Sacrifice of Maidens.
V.16: 16. There was a weird winged God that told us of his wisdom.
V.17: 17. We attained to be starry grains of gold dust in the sands of a slow river.
V.18: 18. Yea, and that river was the river of space and time also.
V.19: 19. We parted thence; ever to the smaller, ever to the greater, until now, O sweet God, we are ourselves, the same.
V.20: 20. O God of mine, Thou art like a little white goat with lightning in his horns!
V.21: 21. I love Thee, I love Thee.
V.22: 22. Every breath, every word, every thought, every deed is an act of love with Thee.
V.23: 23. The beat of my heart is the pendulum of love.
V.24: 24. The songs of me are the soft sighs:
V.25: 25. The thoughts of me are very rapture:
V.26: 26. And my deeds are the myriads of Thy children, the stars and the atoms.
V.28: 28. Let all things drop into this ocean of love!
V.29: 29. Be this devotion a potent spell to exorcise the demons of the Five!
V.30: 30. Ah God, all is gone! Thou dost consummate Thy rapture. Falútli! Falútli!
V.31: 31. There is a solemnity of the silence. There is no more voice at all.
V.32: 32. So shall it be unto the end. We who were dust shall never fall away into the dust.
V.34: 34. Then, O my God, the breath of the Garden of Spices. All these have a savour averse.
V.35: 35. The cone is cut with an infinite ray; the curve of hyperbolic life springs into being.
V.36: 36. Farther and farther we float; yet we are still. It is the chain of systems that is falling away from us.
V.37: 37. First falls the silly world; the world of the old grey land.
V.38: 38. Falls it unthinkably far, with its sorrowful bearded face presiding over it; it fades to silence and woe.
V.39: 39. We to silence and bliss, and the face is the laughing face of Eros.
V.40: 40. Smiling we greet him with the secret signs.
V.41: 41. He leads us into the Inverted Palace.
V.42: 42. There is the Heart of Blood, a pyramid reaching its apex down beyond the Wrong of the Beginning.
V.43: 43. Bury me unto Thy Glory, O beloved, O princely lover of this harlot maiden, within the Secretest Chamber of the Palace!
V.44: 44. It is done quickly; yea, the seal is set upon the vault.
V.45: 45. There is one that shall avail to open it.
V.46: 46. Nor by memory, nor by imagination, nor by prayer, nor by fasting, nor by scourging, nor by drugs, nor by ritual, nor by meditation; only by passive love shall he avail.
V.47: 47. He shall await the sword of the Beloved and bare his throat for the stroke.
V.48: 48. Then shall his blood leap out and write me runes in the sky; yea, write me runes in the sky.

VI.1: 1. Thou wast a priestess, O my God, among the Druids; and we knew the powers of the oak.
VI.2: 2. We made us a temple of stones in the shape of the Universe, even as thou didst wear openly and I concealed.
VI.3: 3. There we performed many wonderful things by midnight.
VI.4: 4. By the waning moon did we work.
VI.5: 5. Over the plain came the atrocious cry of wolves.
VI.6: 6. We answered; we hunted with the pack.
VI.7: 7. We came even unto the new Chapel and Thou didst bear away the Holy Graal beneath Thy Druid vestments.
VI.8: 8. Secretly and by stealth did we drink of the informing sacrament.
VI.9: 9. Then a terrible disease seized upon the folk of the grey land; and we rejoiced.
VI.10: 10. O my God, disguise Thy glory!
VI.11: 11. Come as a thief, and let us steal away the Sacraments!
VI.12: 12. In our groves, in our cloistral cells, in our honeycomb of happiness, let us drink, let us drink!
VI.13: 13. It is the wine that tinges everything with the true tincture of infallible gold.
VI.14: 14. There are deep secrets in these songs. It is not enough to hear the bird; to enjoy song he must be the bird.
VI.15: 15. I am the bird, and Thou art my song, O my glorious galloping God!
VI.16: 16. Thou reinest in the stars; thou drivest the constellations seven abreast through the circus of Nothingness.
VI.18: 18. I play upon mine harp; Thou fightest the beasts and the flames.
VI.19: 19. Thou takest Thy joy in the music, and I in the fighting.
VI.20: 20. Thou and I are beloved of the Emperor.
VI.21:
21. See! he has summoned us to the Imperial dais.
The night falls; it is a great orgy of worship and bliss.
VI.22: 22. The night falls like a spangled cloak from the shoulders of a prince upon a slave.
VI.24: 24. Cast thou, O prophet, the cloak upon these slaves!
VI.25: 25. A great night, and scarce fires therein; but freedom for the slave that its glory shall encompass.
VI.26: 26. So also I went down into the great sad city.
VI.27: 27. There dead Messalina bartered her crown for poison from the dead Locusta; there stood Caligula, and smote the seas of forgetfulness.
VI.28: 28. Who wast Thou, O Caesar, that Thou knewest God in an horse?
VI.29: 29. For lo! we beheld the White Horse of the Saxon engraven upon the earth; and we beheld the Horses of the Sea that flame about the old grey land, and the foam from their nostrils enlightens us!
VI.30: 30. Ah! but I love thee, God!
VI.31: 31. Thou art like a moon upon the ice-world.
VI.32: 32. Thou art like the dawn of the utmost snows upon the burnt-up flats of the tiger’s land.
VI.33: 33. By silence and by speech do I worship Thee.
VI.35: 35. Only Thy silence and Thy speech that worship me avail.
VI.36: 36. Wail, O ye folk of the grey land, for we have drunk your wine, and left ye but the bitter dregs.
VI.37: 37. Yet from these we will distil ye a liquor beyond the nectar of the Gods.
VI.38: 38. There is value in our tincture for a world of Spice and gold.
VI.39: 39. For our red powder of projection is beyond all possibilities.
VI.40: 40. There are few men; there are enough.
VI.41: 41. We shall be full of cup-bearers, and the wine is not stinted.
VI.42: 42. O dear my God! what a feast Thou hast provided.
VI.43: 43. Behold the lights and the flowers and the maidens!
VI.44: 44. Taste of the wines and the cates and the splendid meats!
VI.45: 45. Breathe in the perfumes and the clouds of little gods like wood-nymphs that inhabit the nostrils!
VI.46: 46. Feel with your whole body the glorious smoothness of the marble coolth and the generous warmth of the sun and the slaves!
VI.47: 47. Let the Invisible inform all the devouring Light of its disruptive vigour!
VI.48: 48. Yea! all the world is split apart, as an old grey tree by the lightning!
VI.49: 49. Come, O ye gods, and let us feast.
VI.50: 50. Thou, O my darling, O my ceaseless Sparrow-God, my delight, my desire, my deceiver, come Thou and chirp at my right hand!
VI.51: 51. This was the tale of the memory of Al A’in the priest; yea, of Al A’in the priest.

VII.1: 1. By the burning of the incense was the Word revealed, and by the distant drug.
VII.2: 2. O meal and honey and oil! O beautiful flag of the moon, that she hangs out in the centre of bliss!
VII.3: 3. These loosen the swathings of the corpse; these unbind the feet of Osiris, so that the flaming God may rage through the firmament with his fantastic spear.
VII.4: 4. But of pure black marble is the sorry statue, and the changeless pain of the eyes is bitter to the blind.
VII.5: 5. We understand the rapture of that shaken marble, torn by the throes of the crowned child, the golden rod of the golden God.
VII.6: 6. We know why all is hidden in the stone, within the coffin, within the mighty sepulchre, and we too answer Olalám! Imál! Tutúlu! as it is written in the ancient book.
VII.7: 7. Three words of that book are as life to a new aeon; no god has read the whole.
VII.8: 8. But thou and I, O God, have written it page by page.
VII.9: 9. Ours is the elevenfold reading of the Elevenfold word.
VII.10: 10. These seven letters together make seven diverse words; each word is divine, and seven sentences are hidden therein.
VII.11: 11. Thou art the Word, O my darling, my lord, my master!
VII.12: 12. O come to me, mix the fire and the water, all shall dissolve.
VII.13: 13. I await Thee in sleeping, in waking. I invoke Thee no more; for Thou art in me, O Thou who hast made me a beautiful instrument tuned to Thy rapture.
VII.14: 14. Yet art Thou ever apart, even as I.
VII.15: 15. I remember a certain holy day in the dusk of the year, in the dusk of the Equinox of Osiris, when first I beheld Thee visibly; when first the dreadful issue was fought out; when the Ibis-headed One charmed away the strife.
VII.16: 16. I remember Thy first kiss, even as a maiden should. Nor in the dark byways was there another: Thy kisses abide.
VII.17: 17. There is none other beside Thee in the whole Universe of Love.
VII.18: 18. My God, I love Thee, O Thou goat with gilded horns!
VII.19: 19. Thou beautiful bull of Apis! Thou beautiful serpent of Apep! Thou beautiful child of the Pregnant Goddess!
VII.20: 20. Thou hast stirred in Thy sleep, O ancient sorrow of years! Thou hast raised Thine head to strike, and all is dissolved into the Abyss of Glory.
VII.21: 21. An end to the letters of the words! An end to the sevenfold speech.
VII.22: 22. Resolve me the wonder of it all into the figure of a gaunt swift camel striding over the sand.
VII.23: 23. Lonely is he, and abominable; yet hath he gained the crown.
VII.25: 25. My God! O my God! I am but a speck in the star-dust of ages; I am the Master of the Secret of Things.
VII.26: 26. I am the Revealer and the Preparer. Mine is the Sword — and the Mitre and the Wingèd Wand!
VII.27: 27. I am the Initiator and the Destroyer. Mine is the Globe — and the Bennu bird and the Lotus of Isis my daughter!
VII.28: 28. I am the One beyond these all; and I bear the symbols of the mighty darkness.
VII.29: 29. There shall be a sigil as of a vast black brooding ocean of death and the central blaze of darkness, radiating its night upon all.
VII.30: 30. It shall swallow up that lesser darkness.
VII.31: 31. But in that profound who shall answer: What is?
VII.34: 34. Come, let us no more reason together; let us enjoy! Let us be ourselves, silent, unique, apart.
VII.35: 35. O lonely woods of the world! In what recesses will ye hide our love?
VII.36: 36. The forest of the spears of the Most High is called Night, and Hades, and the Day of Wrath; but I am His captain, and I bear His cup.
VII.37: 37. Fear me not with my spearmen! They shall slay the demons with their petty prongs. Ye shall be free.
VII.38: 38. Ah, slaves! ye will not — ye know not how to will.
VII.39: 39. Yet the music of my spears shall be a song of freedom.
VII.40: 40. A great bird shall sweep from the abyss of Joy, and bear ye away to be my cup-bearers.
VII.41: 41. Come, O my God, in one last rapture let us attain to the Union with the Many!
VII.42: 42. In the silence of Things, in the Night of Forces, beyond the accursèd domain of the Three, let us enjoy our love!
VII.43: 43. My darling! My darling! away, away beyond the Assembly and the Law and the Enlightenment unto an Anarchy of solitude and Darkness!
VII.44: 44. For even thus must we veil the brilliance of our Self.
VII.46: 46. O my God, but the love in Me bursts over the bonds of Space and Time; my love is spilt among them that love not love.
VII.47: 47. My wine is poured out for them that never tasted wine.
VII.48: 48. The fumes thereof shall intoxicate them and the vigour of my love shall breed mighty children from their maidens.
VII.49: 49. Yea! without draught, without embrace: — and the Voice answered Yea! these things shall be.
VII.50: 50. Then I sought a Word for Myself; nay, for myself.
VII.51: 51. And the Word came: O Thou! it is well. Heed naught! I love Thee! I love Thee!
VII.52: 52. Therefore had I faith unto the end of all; yea, unto the end of all.
